item.title: Sudan Live Updates: Attempt at Cease-Fire Appears to Fail as Reports of Fighting Continue
item.description: An announcement of a 24-hour pause in fighting seemed to go unheeded as many residents in Khartoum, the capital, said they remained trapped in their homes and were running low on food, water and supplies.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: How Mexico Became the Biggest User of the Pegasus Spyware
item.description: A Times investigation reveals the story behind how Mexico became the first and most prolific user of Pegasus. It’s still using it, despite promising to stop.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: The NSO Group, the manufacturer of Pegasus spyware, is housed in a few top floors of this building complex in Israel.

item.title: Live Updates: Putin and Zelensky Highlight Separate Trips to Frontline Areas
item.description: Images released on Tuesday of the visits by the Ukrainian leader, Volodymyr Zelensky, and his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, seemed to offer dueling displays of strength. In Moscow, a court upheld the detention of the U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Playing a game in Lukashivka, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: The Wrong Mr. Kozlov: When Sanctions Spell Trouble for Regular People
item.description: After Russia invaded Ukraine, the European Union blacklisted about 1,500 people linked to the war. That has complicated the lives of those who share their sometimes fairly common names.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergej Kozlov teaches Russian in Kaunas, Lithuania. He shares a name with the “chair of the government” of an illegally annexed region in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: India’s Top Court Begins Hearing Same-Sex Marriage Case
item.description: The Supreme Court in recent years has struck down a ban on consensual gay sex. A ruling in favor of legalizing gay unions would make India an outlier in Asia.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Supporters of same-sex marriage at a rally in New Delhi in January.

item.title: At Least 21 Dead After Fire at Beijing Hospital
item.description: The blaze appears to be the deadliest in the past two decades in the city, even though firefighters seemed to extinguish it quickly.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: The aftermath of a fire at Changfeng Hospital in Beijing on Tuesday night.

item.title: Blinken and Top G7 Diplomats Stress Unity on Russia and China
item.description: The foreign ministers of the Group of 7 nations affirmed their shared visions on Russia’s war on Ukraine and China’s assertiveness after talk flared this month over different strategies.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken stressed at a meeting of top diplomats in Japan that the countries spoke with one voice on Russia and China.

item.title: Tunisia Arrests Rachid al-Ghannouchi, Leading Opposition Figure
item.description: Targeting Rachid al-Ghannouchi, the leader of the Islamist Ennahda party, is an escalation in President Kais Saied’s crackdown on dissent.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rachid al-Ghannouchi, leader of the Islamist opposition party Ennahda, at his office in Tunis, Tunisia, in August.

item.title: One Climber Dies and Another Is Missing on Himalayan Mountain
item.description: Noel Hanna, an experienced alpinist, was found dead at a camp after he climbed the summit of Annapurna without supplemental oxygen.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:description: The mountain range that includes Annapurna, in Nepal. The mountain is regarded as particularly deadly among climbers.

item.title: What We Know About Clashes in Sudan Between Military Factions
item.description: The strategically important country in northeastern Africa has been consumed by fighting between two military factions, with plans for a transition to a civilian-led democracy now in shambles.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Smoke rose in Omdurman, Sudan, as fighting broke out on Saturday between two rival military factions in Khartoum, the capital, and around the country.

item.title: Harsh Sentence for Putin Critic Highlights Kremlin’s Repression
item.description: A Moscow court sentenced Vladimir Kara-Murza to 25 years in prison, making it clear that any criticism of the war can lead to prison time.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Moscow City Court, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Moscow City Court showing the Russian opposition figure Vladimir Kara-Murza in court on Monday.

item.title: Russian Invasion of Ukraine Revolutionizes NATO Military Strategy
item.description: Shocked by Russian atrocities, NATO is becoming the war-fighting alliance it was during the Cold War, committed to defending “every inch” of its territory from Day 1.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: American soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division firing artillery during an exercise at the Mihail Kogalniceanu Air Base, near the Black Sea port of Constanta, Romania, last month.

item.title: Seeking to Calm Unrest, Macron Calls for a ‘New Pact of Life and Work’
item.description: But the French president did not yield on the pension change that has roiled the nation. Labor unions declined to meet for talks, and vowed massive protests on May 1.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Monitors in a media control room showing President Emmanuel Macron of France during a televised address to the nation on Monday.

item.title: Freddie Scappaticci, Who May Have Been British Spy ‘Stakeknife,’ Is Dead
item.description: He denied that he was Stakeknife, the code name of a high-ranking British mole in the Irish Republican Army during the Northern Ireland conflict.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell

item.title: How Much Did You Spend on Your Solo Vacation?
item.description: We spoke to readers about their recent solo travels, including their motivations to travel alone and what they chose to spend on.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung

item.title: Covid May Increase the Risk of Type 2 Diabetes, Researchers Find
item.description: Men and people with severe illnesses were more likely to develop the condition within a year. But the data does not prove that the coronavirus causes diabetes.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Jonathan Hayward/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Covid patient in the I.C.U. of a hospital in Surrey, British Columbia. A new study points to higher risks of diabetes among men and those with severe disease.

item.title: Russian Strikes Against Bakhmut Grow Fiercer, Ukraine Says
item.description: According to a top Ukrainian general, Kyiv’s forces remain in control in the ravaged city, the focus of months of fighting, but Russian forces are turning it “into ruins.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of a destroyed square in western Bakhmut in April.

item.title: Russia Court Rejects WSJ Reporter Evan Gershkovich’s Detention Appeal
item.description: It was the first time Mr. Gershkovich, a 31-year-old American, has been seen clearly since he was detained last month.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: The Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich attending a court hearing of the Moscow City Court, on Tuesday.

item.title: Clarence Thomas’s Gifts and the Supreme Court’s Credibility
item.description: Only 25 percent of Americans have a lot of faith in the court.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court faces an acute decline in trust.

item.title: U.S. and European Officials Come Under Attack in Sudan
item.description: The violence against foreign officials, who are usually not targeted, highlighted how much the security situation has worsened in Khartoum in recent days.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken addressed the Sudan crisis during a news conference at the end of a G7 foreign ministers’ meeting in Karuizawa, Japan, on Tuesday.

item.title: A Giant New Telescope Is Taking Shape in Chile’s Atacama Desert
item.description: These days it takes a generation to build a giant telescope. A new one is taking shape in the Atacama Desert in Chile.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye and Marcos Zegers
item.media:description: The foundation of the Giant Magellan Telescope, which will have seven mirrors, each 8.5 meters wide.

item.title: From Bullets to ‘Bird Residue,’ the Many Trials of Telescopes
item.description: Before an observatory can plumb the secrets of the cosmos, it must navigate more humbling challenges.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter detained in Russia, is expected to appear in court.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: The Lefortovo detention center where Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter, is said to be held in Moscow.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Hospitals are attacked in Sudan.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: A satellite image of a damaged hospital in Khartoum, Sudan, on Monday.

item.title: Who Are Sudan’s Rapid Support Forces?
item.description: The unit traces its origins from the notorious Janjaweed militias, which in the 2000s helped Sudan’s Army crush a rebellion in the western region of Darfur.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Members of the Rapid Support Forces in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital, in 2019.

item.title: Tracking the Chemicals in the East Palestine, Ohio, Train Derailment and Fire
item.description: Tankers of vinyl chloride were going halfway across the country, government records show, a trip highlighting the risks of transporting chemicals as plastics production grows.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: The train, passing through a small Ohio town on its multistate trip, was still on fire the day after it derailed on Feb. 3.

item.title: Hospitals and Aid Groups Become Targets as Sudan Fighting Intensifies
item.description: Civilians are caught in the cross-fire, and two rival generals vying for power made it clear their forces had no intention of standing down.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Declan Walsh
item.media:description: A satellite image of a damaged hospital in Khartoum, Sudan, on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Long Sentence for a Putin Critic
item.description: Also, fighting roils Sudan’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Screens at a hall in the Moscow City Court showing a live feed of the verdict against Vladimir Kara-Murza on Monday.

item.title: After American’s Killing in Syria, F.B.I. Builds War Crimes Case Against Top Officials
item.description: The inquiry aims to hold to account Syrian officials considered key architects of a brutal system of detention and torture that has flourished under President Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner and Adam Goldman
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Illustration by Mark Harris. Photographs by Abdulmonam Eassa/Getty Images, Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images, Delil Souleiman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images, via Reuters and via Syrian Network for Human Rights.

item.title: Axel Springer C.E.O. Apologizes for Remarks
item.description: Texts by Mathias Döpfner, the chief executive of the German media giant, included a request urging favorable coverage of a political party. They were published by a rival publication.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Bernd Von Jutrczenka
item.media:description: Axel Springer’s chief executive, Mathias Döpfner, is facing criticism for private comments that have emerged.

item.title: Chinese Worker in Pakistan Is Arrested on Blasphemy Charges
item.description: The arrest of a foreigner under the country’s harsh blasphemy laws, which can lead to the death penalty, is rare and could strain an otherwise warming relationship between China and Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Pakistani demonstrators marched in support of Pakistan’s strict anti-blasphemy laws in the city of Karachi in January.

item.title: Evan Gershkovich, WSJ Reporter Detained in Russia, Has First Consular Visit
item.description: Mr. Gershkovich, 31, was arrested by Russian security services in late March and formally charged with espionage, an accusation that his employer and U.S. officials vehemently deny.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: On Monday, Lynne M. Tracy, the new U.S. ambassador in Moscow, said she had been allowed to see Evan Gershkovich in Moscow’s Lefortovo prison.

item.title: Who Is Vladimir Kara-Murza, Russian Opposition Activist?
item.description: Vladimir Kara-Murza was sentenced on Monday to 25 years in a Russian penal colony.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Vladimir Kara-Murza was sentenced on Monday to 25 years in a Russian penal colony.

item.title: Airbus and Air France Are Acquitted in 2009 Rio-Paris Crash
item.description: Prosecutors had said they would not seek a conviction in the disaster, but the ruling was still a blow for the families of the 228 victims, who fought for years to bring the two companies to court.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Brazilian Navy, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Divers recovered part of the tail of Air France Flight 447 in the Atlantic Ocean in 2009.

item.title: Fox News on Trial
item.description: A lawsuit against Fox News could help decide the boundaries of press freedom.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fox logo in Times Square in Manhattan.

item.title: In Photos: Families of Guatemalans Killed in Migrant Center Fire Bury Their Dead
item.description: The fire in March left 40 people dead.
item.dc:creator: Daniele Volpe and Elda Cantú
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times

item.title: Peering Into Volcanoes at Tanzania’s Crater Highlands
item.description: Uninterested in the extreme altitudes of Kilimanjaro, a writer opted instead to explore the region’s vast calderas, abundant wildlife and rare forms of lava.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Scott

item.title: In Pakistan, Economic Crisis Mutes Ramadan Celebrations
item.description: Rampant inflation, damaged crops and the war in Ukraine have sent food prices soaring during the Muslim holy month of daytime fasting and nighttime feasting.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: An economic crisis in Pakistan has sent the price of goods soaring, muting celebrations for Ramadan. As Ramadan began last month, inflation was at 35.4 percent — the highest in nearly five decades.

item.title: Diplomacy, aid and a court hearing for Evan Gershkovich: What to watch for this week.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of the detained Wall Street Journal journalist Evan Gershkovich in Washington last week.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Chaotic fighting in Sudan.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Planet Labs, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Khartoum International Airport in Sudan on Sunday.

item.title: Sudan Fighting Escalates Amid Fears of Civil War
item.description: The civilian death toll is climbing and concern over a broader conflict is growing as rival generals vie for control of Africa’s third-largest country.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Planet Labs, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Khartoum International Airport in Sudan on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Fighting in Sudan
item.description: Also, an extrajudicial killing on live TV in India.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: People walked along a street as smoke rose above residential buildings in east Khartoum on Sunday.

item.title: How Fighting in Sudan’s Capital Differs from Past Military Conflicts
item.description: Fighting in the country has been far more frequent in the east, west and south instead of its capital, Khartoum.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A policeman in 2011 in Abyei, a dividing line between northern and southern Sudan that was the site of a long-running standoff.

item.title: Under the Shadow of War, Kyiv Celebrates Orthodox Easter
item.description: Thousands of Christians gathered in the Ukrainian capital to mark Holy Week, one year after Ukraine’s army forced Russian troops back from the area around Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Hoffman and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A priest blessing worshipers and their baskets outside an Orthodox Easter service at the Holy Dormition Cathedral in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Killing of Atiq Ahmed in India Renews Alarm About Extrajudicial Violence
item.description: The victim was a former politician, a notorious criminal and a Muslim. Afterward, two government officials described the killing as akin to divine justice.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Investigators at the scene where Atiq Ahmed and his brother were killed in Prayagraj, India, on Saturday.

item.title: A Japanese Island Where the Wild Things Are
item.description: In the pantheon of yokai, spooky beings of Japanese folklore embody anxieties ancient and modern. On Shodoshima, an art contest helps bring new ones to life.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: James Whitlow Delano for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Shodoshima, it is easy to imagine mythological creatures skulking just beyond the eye’s reach.

item.title: Finding the Pentagon Leak Suspect
item.description: How The Times identified the suspect at the center of the Pentagon leak before the authorities announced his name.
item.dc:creator: Mark Scheffler
item.media:description: Jack Teixeira, an Air National Guardsman, in a photo posted on social media.

item.title: E.U. Cries Foul as Poland and Hungary Ban Ukraine Grain Imports
item.description: The European Union lifted tariffs on Ukrainian grain last year. But farmers say they are suffering from a glut of produce in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Vivek Shankar and Enjoli Liston
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Poland has struggled with an excess of grain and other Ukrainian produce since last year, when the European Union lifted tariffs on goods from the country after Russia’s invasion.

item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers Freeze Sperm as a Way to Defy Russia
item.description: Some Ukrainian soldiers are trying to ensure that even if they die in the war, their partners can still build families. They also want to send Russia a message of defiance.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: An embryologist at the IVMED fertility clinic in Kyiv, Ukraine, which says it is freezing the sperm of about 10 soldiers every week. A bill in Parliament would have the government cover the cost of the procedure.

item.title: Ahead of Elections, Turkish Opposition Leader Takes on Erdogan’s Legacy
item.description: Ahead of next month’s elections, Kemal Kilicdaroglu has pledged to undo President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s legacy with a focus on tackling inflation and strengthening democracy.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:description: Kemal Kilicdaroglu, center, in Istanbul last month. Mr. Kilicdaroglu represents six opposition parties in elections next month against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

item.title: What to Know About General Hamdan, Leader of Sudan’s Rapid Support Forces
item.description: A former camel trader who led a militia accused of genocidal violence in Darfur, Lt. Gen. Mohamed Hamdan, widely known as Hemeti, leads the Rapid Support Forces paramilitary unit.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Mohamed Hamdan speaking during a media briefing at the Rapid Support Forces’ headquarters in Khartoum, Sudan, in February.

item.title: Who Is Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan of Sudan?
item.description: Little known before 2019, he rose to power in the aftermath of the military-led coup that ousted Omar Hassan al-Bashir, the longtime leader who was deposed after popular uprisings.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Sudan’s army chief, Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, in March. Hopes of a peaceful transition to democracy were dashed on Saturday when his strained relations with another general in charge turned violent.

item.title: Boy’s Suicide in Poland Spurs Backlash Against State Media Tactics
item.description: A public radio station in the city of Szczecin is under fire for helping to identify a 15-year-old sex abuse victim, the son of a local opposition politician, who later killed himself.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of the neighborhood in Szczecin, Poland, where a 15-year-old sex abuse victim who killed himself in March lived.

item.title: What Leaked Pentagon Documents Say About the Russia-Ukraine War
item.description: Some in Ukraine even welcomed the disclosures as confirming what they have been saying for months — that its forces desperately need more weapons and munitions.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer, Erika Solomon and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery team unloading artillery shells. The leaked Pentagon documents warned of looming shortages of the munitions, but Ukrainian officials have been saying that publicly for months.

item.title: Reconsidering Tax Day
item.description: Make it a time of personal inventory, of looking back and taking account.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Death Toll From Russian Strike in Sloviansk, Ukraine, Climbs
item.description: Rescuers were searching through rubble a day after the city of Sloviansk was struck as fighting raged in Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters trying to rescue residents trapped in the rubble of a residential building in Sloviansk, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: We Want to Hear From Canada Letter Readers
item.description: An overview of what the newsletter is and isn’t and what we try to achieve each week.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The newsroom of The New York Times in Manhattan.
